yeah yeah so we launched what's called
Aurora backtrack and backtrack gives you
the ability to restore your database in
seconds so if there are catastrophic

in the past and have a fresh copy of
your database and it also gives you the
ability not just to do a one-time

back in time in seconds to determine the
right point at which to say this is
where we're restoring back to so even if
I had a backup that was like part of the
way I could figure out which the actual
correct place that I wanted to restore
it was yeah so what's really different
about Aurora backtrack is that it isn't
working with traditional backups or
traditional sort of snapshotting
mechanisms it's actually rewinding the
state of the database to a point in time
so that you're instantaneously available
to use the system as it was at that
point also part of this launch I made a

it was funny
other than the obvious which is everyone

yeah yeah indeed so the first thing to
understand is really Aurora storage is
really quite different than other types
of databases and I might show you a
picture as a place to start we showed
this yesterday when we were talking
about Aurora serverless so the the
nature of Aurora storage is that instead
of having a database with disk drives
attached to the database and then for
high availability moving database
transactions between instances with
Aurora storage we use a shared storage
volume that sits across availability
zones and then instances within our AZ's
attached to that storage and do really
interesting stuff and so Aurora storage
works very differently it's what we call
a log structured storage system which
means that all of the changes that are
being made to the database are being
progressed over a period of time okay so
backtrack is really interesting because
it takes advantage of this log
structured storage to be able to orient
the log oriented storage around this
particular point in time so for example
if you had a timeline of changes that
were being made and in this example t0
is kind of when we started using our
database and then we apply changes as we
go and we make changes up to point t1
well at some point we then say hey look
I'd really like to rewind back to that
point in time because it gave me
something that that I needed to
demonstrate them what we can do is issue
this backtrack command ok and what that
does is it reorient the system back to
that original t1 point in time
everything after that point in time is
invisible it's still in the log
structured storage but from there we can
continue to make changes and those will
happen at the original timestamp that
we've got so t2 t3 and so on and we can
do that as many times as we need so if
we then say look okay we've made some
data changes some data fixes
and now we want to have subsequent
changes made we can rewind again and
again in order to get to the point that
we're happy with the point in time which
makes it a lot more flexible as opposed
to the traditional wage which is either
I am restoring from my snapshot and
maybe you take a snapshot every 12 hours
for every 24 hours or every 36 but
that's kind of get what you get you
either have to restore the whole thing
or you don't restore indeed and the
relational database service all of our

to five minutes of granularity you're

window where you want to get to what's
really different about backtrack is that
where a snapshot has to be restored into
a new database and then you bring in the
changes to your production environment
with backtrack you do it right over the
